fields.summary: Non-answered recursive DNS queries from external clients should return REFUSED, not SERVFAIL

fields.description:
*Assessment*

When using dnsperf with a query file that contains [10 million entries|ftp://ftp.nominum.com/pub/nominum/dnsperf/data/queryfile-example-10million-201202.gz], Eucalyptus DNS doesn't display the same performance as other DNS servers.  The tests were performed in the following scenarios:
* From an instance running on a cloud where Eucalyptus DNS is enabled (CLC is main nameserver in /etc/resolv.conf)
{quote}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         263193
  Queries completed:    261362 (99.30%)
  Queries lost:         1831 (0.70%)

  *Response codes:       NOERROR 210092 (80.38%), SERVFAIL 23112 (8.84%), NXDOMAIN 28158 (10.77%)*
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 210
  Run time (s):         1801.838036
  Queries per second:   145.052993

  Average Latency (s):  0.600334 (min 0.421676, max 47.910730)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.286022
{quote}
* From an external client querying the CLC where Eucalyptus DNS is enabled
{quote}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         257378
  Queries completed:    257249 (99.95%)
  Queries lost:         129 (0.05%)

  *Response codes:       NOERROR 60 (0.02%), SERVFAIL 254460 (98.92%), NXDOMAIN 2729 (1.06%)*
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 38
  Run time (s):         1800.636473
  Queries per second:   142.865594

  Average Latency (s):  0.670382 (min 2.116448, max 16.665694)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.119450
{quote}
Comparative tests covered the following scenarios:
* From an AWS instance to the instance's nameserver (defined in /etc/resolv.conf)
{quote}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         1690084
  Queries completed:    1682590 (99.56%)
  Queries lost:         7494 (0.44%)

  *Response codes:       NOERROR 1472669 (87.52%), SERVFAIL 12508 (0.74%), NXDOMAIN 197413 (11.73%)*
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 109
  Run time (s):         1804.945245
  Queries per second:   932.211104

  Average Latency (s):  0.081113 (min 0.000776, max 49.760688)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.226305
{quote}
* Against 10.1.1.254
{quote}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         1558839
  Queries completed:    1548127 (99.31%)
  Queries lost:         10712 (0.69%)

  *Response codes:       NOERROR 1346662 (86.99%), SERVFAIL 12470 (0.81%), NXDOMAIN 188995 (12.21%)*
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 221
  Run time (s):         1804.200412
  Queries per second:   858.068200

  Average Latency (s):  0.078215 (min 0.001616, max 49.340814)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.168321
{quote}
* Against 8.8.8.8
{quote}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         384217
  Queries completed:    359787 (93.64%)
  Queries lost:         24430 (6.36%)

  *Response codes:       NOERROR 312693 (86.91%), SERVFAIL 3367 (0.94%), NXDOMAIN 43708 (12.15%), REFUSED 19 (0.01%)*
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 107
  Run time (s):         1803.165729
  Queries per second:   199.530744

  Average Latency (s):  0.151815 (min 0.360027, max 48.137890)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.318152
{quote}

*Signs*

SERVFAIL is higher when using dnsperf against the CLC (Eucalyptus DNS), than other DNS servers.

*Steps*
\\
\\
*_Note: To see exactly where SERVFAIL errors occurred, run the dnsperf command with the '-v' option_*
# Set up Eucalyptus 4.0.0 Cloud with Eucalyptus DNS enabled (following the steps in the [Eucalyptus 4.0 documentation|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/setting_up_dns.html]).
# Set up reverse map for public IPs used for the cloud (similar to what was mentioned in [ticket IT-269|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/IT-269?focusedCommentId=72126&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-72126]
*From an instance running on the cloud*
# Launch a CentOS 6.5 instance, SSH into the instance and install the 'dnsperf' package
# Download the [10 million query example file|ftp://ftp.nominum.com/pub/nominum/dnsperf/data/queryfile-example-10million-201202.gz] from Nominum (the guys who developed dnsperf)
# After decompressing the query file (e.g. gzip -d <file>), run the dnsperf command as follows:
{code}
dnsperf -s <CLC-IP> -d queryfile-example-10million-201202 -n 10 -l 1800 -c 10
{code}
# Observe output
*External client querying Eucalyptus DNS (i.e. CLC)*
# Use a CentOS 6.5 machine or Mac OS X machine with 'dnsperf' installed
# Download the [10 million entry query file|ftp://ftp.nominum.com/pub/nominum/dnsperf/data/queryfile-example-10million-201202.gz]
# Run 'dnsperf' as follows:
{code}
dnsperf -s <CLC-IP> -d queryfile-example-10million-201202 -n 10 -l 1800 -c 10
{code}
# Observe the output
* Eucalyptus DNS configuration
** cloud properties for DNS
{code}
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_dns_delegation	true
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_instance_dns	true
PROPERTY	dns.dns_listener_address_match	{}
PROPERTY	dns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.instancedata.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.ns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.recursive.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.hostmapping	{}
PROPERTY	dns.split_horizon.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.region_name	{}
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.tcp.timeout_seconds	30
PROPERTY	loadbalancing.loadbalancer_dns_subdomain	elb
PROPERTY	objectstorage.s3provider.s3usebackenddns	false
PROPERTY	system.dns.dnsdomain	acme.eucalyptus-systems.com
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserver	odc-f-13.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserveraddress	10.104.10.55
PROPERTY	system.dns.registrationid	bc11a78a-7d46-4efa-a9dd-8096a0732984
{code}
** VNET_DNS entry in CC's eucalyptus.conf
{code}
[root@odc-d-31 ~]# grep VNET_DNS /etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf
VNET_DNS="8.8.8.8"
{code}

*Pertinent Data*

* dnsperf was used in EUCA-8633 to confirm that the issue in EUCA-8633 was resolved, however we didn't confirm that we responded accurately to the queries.  The issue in EUCA-8633 was not seen in testing.
* For more information regarding SERVFAIL, NOERROR, NXDOMAIN return codes, please refer to [the section 'RCODE Assignment' in RFC 2929|http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2929#section-2.3]
fields.summary: Eucalyptus DNS returns SERVFAIL too frequently
fields.environment:
* non-HA, single cluster, Managed mode
* 1 x CLC (Eucalyptus DNS)
* 1 x UFS
* 1 x UFS + Walrus
* 1 x CC/SC (Overlay)
* 2 x NC

comments.body: One bug:  most of the requests from external clients should be resulting in REFUSED codes, not SERVFAIL codes.

[~hspencer] I see the CustomerAffecting flag is set. Can you confirm if the current customers are directly or indirectly affected by this result?
[~gholms] I agree. Fixing it though is not trivial because the current implementation didn't consider the error cases...
The issue with REFUSED vs SERVFAIL will be tracked in EUCA-9964.

The main issue was that our recursive resolver worked for only A and AAAA types, while most of the SERVFAIL comes from MX queries. To fix this, patch is made to allow MX types as well.
There might still be issues other types of recursive queries. 

This is the result after the fix.

  Queries sent:         164186
  Queries completed:    162219 (98.80%)
  Queries lost:         1967 (1.20%)

  Response codes:       NOERROR 141007 (86.92%), SERVFAIL 1367 (0.84%), NXDOMAIN 19845 (12.23%)
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 218
  Run time (s):         1801.834847
  Queries per second:   90.029894

  Average Latency (s):  0.983423 (min 1.428964, max 49.446440)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.420577
How much work is it to make recursive queries work for all record types?

I am still seeing too many SERVFAIL
{code}
dnsperf -s 10.111.5.13 -d queryfile-example-10million-201202 -n 10 -l 1800 -c 10

Statistics:

  Queries sent:         274243
  Queries completed:    273374 (99.68%)
  Queries lost:         869 (0.32%)

  Response codes:       SERVFAIL 270463 (98.94%), NXDOMAIN 2911 (1.06%)
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 38
  Run time (s):         1800.591156
  Queries per second:   151.824582

  Average Latency (s):  0.642452 (min 1.111098, max 41.707013)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.121728
  
[h-13:~]euca-describe-properties  dns
PROPERTY	dns.dns_listener_address_match	{}
PROPERTY	dns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.instancedata.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.ns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.recursive.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.hostmapping	{}
PROPERTY	dns.split_horizon.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.enabled	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.region_name	{}
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.tcp.timeout_seconds	30
{code}
Did you run the test within the instance? Euca DNS does not allow recursive queries for external clients.

[~spark]  So it is the test below we are addressing with the fix, where the  SERVFAIL 23112 (8.84%) is too high right? I ran the test from an external client.
{code}
From an instance running on a cloud where Eucalyptus DNS is enabled (CLC is main nameserver in /etc/resolv.conf)
Statistics:
Queries sent: 263193
Queries completed: 261362 (99.30%)
Queries lost: 1831 (0.70%)
Response codes: NOERROR 210092 (80.38%), SERVFAIL 23112 (8.84%), NXDOMAIN 28158 (10.77%)
Average packet size: request 38, response 210
Run time (s): 1801.838036
Queries per second: 145.052993
Average Latency (s): 0.600334 (min 0.421676, max 47.910730)
Latency StdDev (s): 0.286022
{code}
[~mmunn1] Yes. SERVFAIL should be comparable to other DNS servers (0.7-0.9 %).  The test should be run from the VM.

Looks good when run from an instance.
{code}
Statistics:

  Queries sent:         137178
  Queries completed:    136215 (99.30%)
  Queries lost:         963 (0.70%)

  Response codes:       NOERROR 118703 (87.14%), SERVFAIL 1107 (0.81%), NXDOMAIN 16405 (12.04%)
  Average packet size:  request 38, response 218
  Run time (s):         1803.095927
  Queries per second:   75.545066

  Average Latency (s):  1.212991 (min 3.891397, max 49.191551)
  Latency StdDev (s):   0.360079
{code}
